   <div class="section" id="pyqtgraph-s-3d-graphics-system">
 <h1>Pyqtgraph&#8217;s 3D Graphics System<a class="headerlink" href="#pyqtgraph-s-3d-graphics-system" title="Permalink to this headline">¶</a></h1>
 <p>The 3D graphics system in pyqtgraph is composed of a <a class="reference internal" href="glviewwidget.html#pyqtgraph.opengl.GLViewWidget" title="pyqtgraph.opengl.GLViewWidget"><tt class="xref py py-class docutils literal"><span class="pre">view</span> <span class="pre">widget</span></tt></a> and
-several graphics items (all subclasses of <a class="reference internal" href="glgraphicsitem.html#pyqtgraph.opengl.GLGraphicsItem" title="pyqtgraph.opengl.GLGraphicsItem"><tt class="xref py py-class docutils literal"><span class="pre">GLGraphicsItem</span></tt></a>) which
+several graphics items (all subclasses of <tt class="xref py py-class docutils literal"><span class="pre">GLGraphicsItem</span></tt>) which
 can be added to a view widget.</p>
 <p><strong>Note:</strong> use of this system requires python-opengl bindings. Linux users should install the python-opengl
 packages from their distribution. Windows/OSX users can download from <a class="reference external" href="http://pyopengl.sourceforge.net">http://pyopengl.sourceforge.net</a>.</p>

             if in the global xy plane and points to the right side of the view,
             y is in the global xy plane and orthogonal to x, and z points in
             the global z direction. Distances are scaled roughly such that a
             value of 1.0 moves by one pixel on screen.
         pixelSize(ppooss)_¶
             Return the approximate size of a screen pixel at the location pos
             Pos may be a Vector or an (N,3) array of locations

+            Read the current buffer pixels out as a QImage.

+<dd><p>Causes python to exit without garbage-collecting any objects, and thus avoids
+calling object destructor methods. This is a sledgehammer workaround for 
+a variety of bugs in PyQt and Pyside that cause crashes on exit.</p>
+<p>This function does the following in an attempt to &#8216;safely&#8217; terminate
+the process:</p>
+<ul class="simple">
+<li>Invoke atexit callbacks</li>
+<li>Close all open file handles</li>
+<li>os._exit()</li>
+</ul>
+<p>Note: there is some potential for causing damage with this function if you
+are using objects that _require_ their destructors to be called (for example,
+to properly terminate log files, disconnect from devices, etc). Situations
+like this are probably quite rare, but use at your own risk.</p>
+</dd></dl>

+<dd><p>Enable (or disable) automatic SI prefix scaling on this axis.</p>
+<p>When enabled, this feature automatically determines the best SI prefix 
+to prepend to the label units, while ensuring that axis values are scaled
+accordingly.</p>

+to &#8216;V&#8217; then the axis would display values -100 to 100
+and the units would appear as &#8216;mV&#8217;</p>
+<p>This feature is enabled by default, and is only available when a suffix
+(unit string) is provided to display on the label.</p>

+<span class="c">## PyQt and PySide both are prone to crashing on exit. </span>
+<span class="c">## There are two general approaches to dealing with this:</span>
+<span class="c">##  1. Install atexit handlers that assist in tearing down to avoid crashes.</span>
+<span class="c">##     This helps, but is never perfect.</span>
+<span class="c">##  2. Terminate the process before python starts tearing down</span>
+<span class="c">##     This is potentially dangerous</span>
 
+<span class="c">## Attempts to work around exit crashes:</span>
 <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">atexit</span>
 <span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">cleanup</span><span class="p">():</span>
+    <span class="k">if</span> <span class="ow">not</span> <span class="n">getConfigOption</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s">&#39;exitCleanup&#39;</span><span class="p">):</span>
+        <span class="k">return</span>
+

     <span class="c">## Workaround for Qt exit crash:</span>
     <span class="c">## ALL QGraphicsItems must have a scene before they are deleted.</span>
     <span class="c">## This is potentially very expensive, but preferred over crashing.</span>
     <span class="c">## Note: this appears to be fixed in PySide as of 2012.12, but it should be left in for a while longer..</span>
     <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">QtGui</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">QApplication</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">instance</span><span class="p">()</span> <span class="ow">is</span> <span class="bp">None</span><span class="p">:</span>

+<span class="c">## Optional function for exiting immediately (with some manual teardown)</span>
+<div class="viewcode-block" id="exit"><a class="viewcode-back" href="../functions.html#pyqtgraph.exit">[docs]</a><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">exit</span><span class="p">():</span>
+    <span class="sd">&quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
+<span class="sd">    Causes python to exit without garbage-collecting any objects, and thus avoids</span>
+<span class="sd">    calling object destructor methods. This is a sledgehammer workaround for </span>
+<span class="sd">    a variety of bugs in PyQt and Pyside that cause crashes on exit.</span>
+<span class="sd">    </span>
+<span class="sd">    This function does the following in an attempt to &#39;safely&#39; terminate</span>
+<span class="sd">    the process:</span>
+<span class="sd">    </span>
+<span class="sd">    * Invoke atexit callbacks</span>
+<span class="sd">    * Close all open file handles</span>
+<span class="sd">    * os._exit()</span>
+<span class="sd">    </span>
+<span class="sd">    Note: there is some potential for causing damage with this function if you</span>
+<span class="sd">    are using objects that _require_ their destructors to be called (for example,</span>
+<span class="sd">    to properly terminate log files, disconnect from devices, etc). Situations</span>
+<span class="sd">    like this are probably quite rare, but use at your own risk.</span>
+<span class="sd">    &quot;&quot;&quot;</span>
+    
+    <span class="c">## first disable our own cleanup function; won&#39;t be needing it.</span>
+    <span class="n">setConfigOptions</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">exitCleanup</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="bp">False</span><span class="p">)</span>
+    
+    <span class="c">## invoke atexit callbacks</span>
+    <span class="n">atexit</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_run_exitfuncs</span><span class="p">()</span>
+    
+    <span class="c">## close file handles</span>
+    <span class="n">os</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">closerange</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">4096</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c">## just guessing on the maximum descriptor count..</span>
+    
+    <span class="n">os</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">_exit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
+    
+

+import threading
+class FileForwarder(threading.Thread):
+    """
+    Background thread that forwards data from one pipe to another. 
+    This is used to catch data from stdout/stderr of the child process
+    and print it back out to stdout/stderr. We need this because this
+    bug: http://bugs.python.org/issue3905  _requires_ us to catch
+    stdout/stderr.
+
+    *output* may be a file or 'stdout' or 'stderr'. In the latter cases,
+    sys.stdout/stderr are retrieved once for every line that is output,
+    which ensures that the correct behavior is achieved even if 
+    sys.stdout/stderr are replaced at runtime.
+    """
+    def __init__(self, input, output):
+        threading.Thread.__init__(self)
+        self.input = input
+        self.output = output
+        self.lock = threading.Lock()
+        self.start()
+
+    def run(self):
+        if self.output == 'stdout':
+            while True:
+                line = self.input.readline()
+                with self.lock:
+                    sys.stdout.write(line)
+        elif self.output == 'stderr':
+            while True:
+                line = self.input.readline()
+                with self.lock:
+                    sys.stderr.write(line)
+        else:
+            while True:
+                line = self.input.readline()
+                with self.lock:
+                    self.output.write(line)
+

+def exit():
+    """
+    Causes python to exit without garbage-collecting any objects, and thus avoids
+    calling object destructor methods. This is a sledgehammer workaround for 
+    a variety of bugs in PyQt and Pyside that cause crashes on exit.
+

+    the process:
+    
+    * Invoke atexit callbacks
+    * Close all open file handles
+    * os._exit()
+    
+    Note: there is some potential for causing damage with this function if you
+    are using objects that _require_ their destructors to be called (for example,
+    to properly terminate log files, disconnect from devices, etc). Situations
+    like this are probably quite rare, but use at your own risk.
+    """
+    
+    ## first disable our own cleanup function; won't be needing it.
+    setConfigOptions(exitCleanup=False)
+    
+    ## invoke atexit callbacks
+    atexit._run_exitfuncs()
+    
+    ## close file handles

+
